jsp.scene.pointOfView.title: Point of view
jsp.scene.pointOfView.subtitle: From which point of view is the scene narrated?
common_pointOfView_1stOnMajor.popover: The scene is narrated in the first person by one of the main characters. The scene is filtered through that characterʼs senses and thoughts: this means that the narration must be coherent with that characterʼs intelligence and vocabulary. The character can only narrate events, of which they are aware.
common_pointOfView_1stOnMinor.popover: The scene is narrated in the first person by a secondary character, who is not the protagonist of the narrated events. This point of view must be used if the main characters are not aware of their actions and therefore are not able to narrate their story correctly. This type of narrator does not know main charactersʼ thoughts and can narrate only events that they have witnessed.
common_pointOfView_3rdLimited.popover: The scene is narrated in the third person by an external narrator, who only has access to a main characterʼs thoughts and actions. This type of narration is freer than in first person and is not necessarily coherent with the intelligence and language of the character. The character narrates only event they actually know.
common_pointOfView_3rdOmniscient.popover: The scene is narrated in the third person by an external narrator, that has access to all charactersʼ thoughts as well as to all the events -- past, present and future -- including events that no character could know.
common_pointOfView_3rdObjective.popover: The scene is narrated in the third person by an external narrator, who has no access to any characterʼs thoughts. This type of narration has a journalistic style. The narrator has access to all the events, but the narration can only be developed only through actions and dialogues.
common_pointOfView_2nd.popover: This scene is narrated in the second person by an external narrator, who addresses the reader directly.

jsp.characterInfo.question: Question
characterInfo_question_personaldata_free: Insert characterʼs personal data: first name, surname, nickname, gender, age, birthplace, residence, education, financial situation.
characterInfo_question_personaldata_2: nickname? Where does it come from?
characterInfo_question_personaldata_7: what is their level of education?
characterInfo_question_personaldata_10: which kind of house do they live in? Villa? Apartment?
characterInfo_question_personaldata_11: do they own their home or do they rent?
characterInfo_question_physionomy_freeTe: Describe characterʼs physical features: eyes, hair, mouth, nose, ear, hands, body, build, height, weight, race.
characterInfo_question_physionomy_5: what are their eyes like? Do they wear glasses?
characterInfo_question_physionomy_7: what are their mouth and teeth like?
characterInfo_question_physionomy_10: do they have a moustache or beard?
characterInfo_question_physionomy_14: what are their hands like? Are they left-handed or right-handed?
characterInfo_question_physionomy_16: what are their waist and hips like?
characterInfo_question_physionomy_18: what are their legs and ankles like?
characterInfo_question_physionomy_22: do they have any scars or other particular markings?
characterInfo_question_physionomy_23: do they have any tattoos or body piercings?
characterInfo_question_behaviors_freeTex: Describe characterʼs attitude/behaviour: way of looking, laughing, talking, crying, walking, dressing, drinking, eating.
characterInfo_question_behaviors_1: what is their way of speaking?
characterInfo_question_behaviors_5: are they well mannered and refined, or ill-mannered and coarse?
characterInfo_question_behaviors_7: what is their style? Are they elegant or not?
characterInfo_question_behaviors_8: do they wear make-up and how is it applied?
characterInfo_question_behaviors_9: do they wear cologne or perfume?
characterInfo_question_behaviors_11: how do they eat and drink?
characterInfo_question_sociology_freeTex: Describe their relationship with their partner, family, friends, schoolmates, colleagues.
characterInfo_question_sociology_0: how is their relationship with their partner?
characterInfo_question_sociology_1: how is their relationship with their father?
characterInfo_question_sociology_2: how is their relationship with their mother?
characterInfo_question_sociology_3: how is their relationship with their siblings?
characterInfo_question_sociology_4: how is their relationship with their grandparents?
characterInfo_question_sociology_5: how is their relationship with their cousins/uncles?
characterInfo_question_sociology_6: how is their relationship with their teachers?
characterInfo_question_sociology_7: how is their relationship with their schoolmates?
characterInfo_question_sociology_8: how is their relationship with their friends?
characterInfo_question_sociology_9: how is their relationship with their colleagues, bosses, clients?
characterInfo_question_psychology_freeTe: Describe all the aspects of characterʼs psychology.
characterInfo_question_psychology_2: how do they feel most frequently? Happy or sad?
characterInfo_question_psychology_3: are they generous or selfish? Are they self-centred?
characterInfo_question_psychology_5: are they anxious? Are they apprehensive?
characterInfo_question_psychology_6: are they nice or unpleasant? Are they funny or boring?
characterInfo_question_psychology_11: do they tend to be passive?
characterInfo_question_psychology_14: do they tend to lie or are they sincere? Are they frank?
characterInfo_question_psychology_15: are they calm or bad-tempered? Nervous? Pugnacious? Violent?
characterInfo_question_psychology_16: are they goal-oriented with consistent goals, or are they fickle?
characterInfo_question_psychology_18: are they intellectual or do they tend to be more pragmatic?
characterInfo_question_psychology_19: are they cynical or idealistic? Are they down to earth or a dreamer?
characterInfo_question_psychology_20: are they consistent with their ideas?
characterInfo_question_psychology_21: are they understanding and indulgent or severe?
characterInfo_question_psychology_24: are they discreet or tends to gossip?
characterInfo_question_psychology_29: are they sweet and affectionate or harsh?
characterInfo_question_psychology_30: are they fussy and meticulous? Are they diligent?
characterInfo_question_psychology_34: are they jealous? Are they possessive?
characterInfo_question_psychology_37: are they impulsive or thoughtful? Are they cautious?
characterInfo_question_psychology_40: are they self-confident? Do they trust their own capacities?
characterInfo_question_psychology_55: can they forgive or do they harbour resentment?
characterInfo_question_psychology_56: do they have a sense of justice?
characterInfo_question_psychology_57: are they friendly and extroverted or more introverted?
characterInfo_question_psychology_61: are they unstable and capricious? Are they moody?
characterInfo_question_ideas_freeText: Describe characterʼs religious beliefs, political views, passions, hobbies, manias, vices.
characterInfo_question_ideas_3: do they like sport? Do they play any sport? Are they a fan?
characterInfo_question_ideas_4: do they appreciate art? How do they express it?
characterInfo_question_ideas_5: do they have a passion for art?
characterInfo_question_ideas_6: do they like literature? Favourite novel?
characterInfo_question_ideas_7: do they like music? Favourite song?
characterInfo_question_ideas_8: do they like cinema? Favourite movie?
characterInfo_question_ideas_10: do they love animals? Do they have any pets?
characterInfo_question_ideas_11: do they love travelling? Favourite trips or adventures?
characterInfo_question_ideas_12: do they like good cooking? Do they like to cook?
characterInfo_question_ideas_14: what are their usual means of transport?

jsp.info.p.author: Andrea Feccomandi
jsp.info.p.credits.4: Gaspar Fernández, Jose Maria Radillo Villegas (spanish translation)
jsp.info.p.credits.7: Volker Bender, Andre Jonas, Wolfram Wagner (german translation)
jsp.info.p.credits.8: Nicolas Alucq, Étienne Morin, Pierre-Yves Souchet, Simon Yergeau (french translation)
jsp.info.p.credits.9: Davi Felipe F. L. Rodrigues (portuguese(Brazil) translation)

jsp.info.p.project.1: This is a personal project, made with love.
jsp.info.p.project.2: We love books and we want to help writers to write beautiful novels.
jsp.suggestedReadings.h1.title: Suggested readings
jsp.suggestedReadings.p.1: You will need more than just inspiration and talent to write your novel.
jsp.suggestedReadings.p.2: You will need love, perseverance and courage. You will also need to study the dramaturgy of the masters.
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.egri.title: Art Of Dramatic Writing: Its Basis in the Creative Interpretation of Human Motives
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.egri.descript: Learn the basic techniques every successful playwright knows Among the many "how-to" playwriting books that have appeared over the years, there have been few that attempt to analyze the mysteries of play construction. Lajos Egriʼs classic, The Art of Dramatic Writing, does just that, with instruction that can be applied equally well to a short story, novel, or screenplay. Examining a play from the inside out, Egri starts with the heart of any drama: its characters. All good dramatic writing hinges on people and their relationships, which serve to move the story forward and give it life, as well as an understanding of human motives -- why people act the way that they do. Using examples from everything from William Shakespeareʼs Romeo and Juliet to Henrik Ibsenʼs A Dollʼs House, Egri shows how it is essential for the author to have a basic premise -- a thesis, demonstrated in terms of human behavior -- and to develop the dramatic conflict on the basis of that behavior. Using Egriʼs ABCs of premise, character, and conflict, The Art of Dramatic Writing is a direct, jargon-free approach to the problem of achieving truth in writing.
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.gotham.title: Writing Fiction: The Practical Guide from New Yorkʼs Acclaimed Creative Writing School
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.gotham.author: by Gotham Writersʼ Workshop
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.gotham.descri: Gotham Writersʼ Workshop has mastered the art of teaching the craft of writing in a way that is practical, accessible, and entertaining. Now the techniques of this renowned school are available in this book. Here youʼll find: 1) The fundamental elements of fiction craft-character, plot, point of view, etc.-explained clearly and completely 2) Key concepts illustrated with passages from great works of fiction 3) The complete text of "Cathedral" by Raymond Carver-a masterpiece of contemporary short fiction that is analyzed throughout the book	4) Exercises that let you immediately apply what you learn to your own writing.	Written by Gotham Writersʼ Workshop expert instructors and edited by Dean of Faculty Alexander Steele, Writing Fiction offers the same methods and exercises that have earned the school international acclaim. Once youʼve read-and written-your way through this book, youʼll have a command of craft that will enable you to turn your ideas into effective short stories and novels. You will be a writer.
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.vogler.title: The Writers Journey: Mythic Structure for Writers, 3rd Edition
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.vogler.author: by Christopher Vogler (Author, Michele Montez (Illustrator)
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.vogler.descri: The updated and revised third edition provides new insights and observations from Voglerʼs ongoing work on mythologyʼs influence on stories, movies, and man himself. The previous two editons of this book have sold over 180,000 units, making this book a ʼclassicʼ for screenwriters, writers, and novelists.
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.marks.title: Inside story - The Power of the Transformational Arc
jsp.suggestedReadings.book.marks.descrip: What is the secret to writing a great screenplay? Whether youʼre a beginning screenwriter or an A-list Academy Award winner, all writers struggle with the same thing: to get to the great script inside. Step by step, Inside Story: The Power of the Transformational Arc guides you through an extraordinary new process that helps identify your thematic intention-what your story is really about-and teaches you how to turn that intention into the driving force behind all your creative choices. The result is a profound relationship between the movement of the plot and the internal development of character, which is the foundation for the transformational arc. The transformational arc is the deeper line of structure found inside the story. Knowing how to work with the arc enhances your ability to: 1) Express your unique point of view 2) Give meaning and urgency to the line of action 3) Infuse your characters with richness, subtlety, and surprise 4) Develop a powerful emotional undercurrent 5) Make your stories stand out and get attention A strong transformational arc is the single most important element that makes the difference between a good screenplay and a great one. Inside Story delivers what the name implies: itʼs the real inside scoop on how to write a great screenplay with depth, dimension, and substance. It is a must-have for any serious screenwriter, playwright, or novelist.
jsp.suggestions.characters.h4: 1. Have a deep relationship with your characters
jsp.suggestions.characters.p1: Novels only work if their characters are believable.
jsp.suggestions.characters.p2: Characters are believable when you can understand the complexity of their human nature: e.g. qualities, defects, contradictions.
jsp.suggestions.characters.p3: Characters that are completely good or completely evil are stereotypes and therefore are not believable.
jsp.suggestions.characters.p4: In order to create believable characters, you must know everything about them: physical aspect, behavior, psychology, sociology, ideas, passions, life before the beginning of the novel.
jsp.suggestions.conflict.h4: 2. Every main character has a conflict
jsp.suggestions.conflict.p1: The main charactersʼ conflict is the driving force of the novel: it is an inner need, a desire to be realised, or the reaction to an external situation.
jsp.suggestions.conflict.p2: Conflict leads a character to action and to change the condition of things.
jsp.suggestions.conflict.p3: A novel is the story of a change in the condition of things, and of the main characterʼs evolution during this process.
jsp.suggestions.conflict.p4: There is no novel without conflict.
jsp.suggestions.premise.p1: The premise contains the entire novel in just one sentence: conflict and its resolution.
jsp.suggestions.premise.p2: Letʼs suppose your novel to be about a young man that leaves his small town to go to New York, to make his fortune as an actor. After several failures and humiliations, he finally achieves success. In this case, the premise could be: desire to perform (conflict) and determination lead to success (resolution).
jsp.suggestions.premise.p3: Premise is the guide to the novel: the conclusion must start from conflict.
jsp.suggestions.premise.p4: If the premise is clear, everything comes easier. For example, for our aspiring actor, determination and artistic sense could be revealed in the first chapters, by narrating that during his childhood he passed an entire summer helping his grandmother decorate one of her kitchen walls, creating a huge mosaic of every kind of fruit and vegetable.
jsp.suggestions.setting.p1: Your characters act in a well-defined space and time that deeply influences them.
jsp.suggestions.setting.p2: For example, something that can be considered outrageous in a small town in the 1800s, would be well accepted in New York in 2010.
jsp.suggestions.setting.p3: Therefore, in order to make the novel plausible, it is essential first to understand its setting, i.e. space and time.
jsp.suggestions.fabula.p1: Fabula is narration of the events in the order of their logical-temporal sequence.
jsp.suggestions.fabula.p2: First of all, you have to briefly define the novelʼs fabula, irrespective of the plot, that is the order in which events are presented (linear narration, flashbacks, previews).
jsp.suggestions.fabula.p3: Once you have entirely defined the fabula, it will be easier for you to determine the most effective way to develop the plot.
jsp.suggestions.pointofview.h4: 6. How is the story narrated? Choose the point of view.
jsp.suggestions.pointofview.p1: Each point of view has specific features, with pros and cons. Here you have an overview.
jsp.suggestions.pointofview.p2: First person: the story is narrated in the first person by one of the main characters. The story is filtered through that characterʼs senses and thoughts: this means narration must be coherent with their intelligence and vocabulary. The character can only narrate events they actually know.
jsp.suggestions.pointofview.p3: Secondary first person: the story is narrated in the first person by a secondary character, who is not the protagonist of narrated events. This point of view must be used if main characters are not aware of their actions and therefore are not able to narrate their story correctly. The narrator does not know the main charactersʼ thoughts and can narrate only events that they have witnessed.
jsp.suggestions.pointofview.p4: Limited third person: the story is narrated in the third person by an external narrator, that only has access to a main characterʼs thoughts and actions. Narration is freer than in the first person and is not necessarily coherent with intelligence and language of the character. The character narrates only events they actually know.
jsp.suggestions.pointofview.p5: Omniscient third person: the story is narrated in the third person by an external narrator, who has access to all charactersʼ thoughts as well as to all the events, past, present and future, including events that no character knows.
jsp.suggestions.pointofview.p6: Objective third person: the story is narrated in the third person by an external narrator, that has no access to any characterʼs thoughts. Narration has a journalistic style. Narrator has access to all the events, but narration must be developed only through actions and dialogues.
jsp.suggestions.pointofview.p7: Second person: the story is narrated in the second person by an external narrator that addresses the reader directly.

jsp.analysis.importantNote.alert.text: In order to be able to analyse the data completely, you must create the sceneʼs tags section. The tags section collects information related to characters present in the scene, location and time of the scene, narrative point of view, and narrative strands to which the scene belongs.

relations_delete_relation_confirm: Are you sure you want to delete this relation?
relations_export_diagram_label: Select the directory into which bibisco will export relations' diagram
relations_add_element_instructions: double click in an empty space to place a new element
relations_edit_delete_element_instructio: double click on an element to edit or delete it
relations_edit_delete_relation_instructi: double click on a relation to edit or delete it
relations_add_relation_instructions: click on a element and drag the edge to another element to connect them
relations_move_element_instructions: hold shift key and drag element
goals_words_written_average_last_7_days: words written on average in the last seven days
goals_words_written_last_30_days: Words written in the last 30 days
goals_calculate_tooltip: words per day = (words total goal - words written) / days left to deadline
jsp.project.button.updateAuthor: change the name of the author
epub_cover_image_placeholder: Select the cover image for your ebook
daily_tracking_enabled_from_2_2_0: The daily word tracking feature is active since version 2.2.0 of bibisco. Words written using previous versions are not tracked, but are considered in the total word count of the novel.
backup_reminder: bibisco is a desktop application that stores data on your PC/Mac. Remember to make regular backups by exporting your project as an archive and in docx format!
character_events_subtitle: major events in the life of the character
location_events_subtitle: major events in the history of the location
object_events_subtitle: major events in the history of the object
delete_event_confirm: Do you really want to delete this event?
note_delete_confirm: Are you sure you want to delete this note?
note_change_name_title: Change the title of the note
note_change_name_label: change the title of the note
add_profile_image_tip: If you want to change the selected profile image, go to the images section and select an image from those present.
delete_part_confirm: Do you really want to delete this part? Please note: the chapters present in the part will not be deleted, but they will be moved to the nearest part
analysis_noitem_available_objects: Analysis is not available, because you havenʼt created any objects yet.
max_backup_number_note: When the maximum number of backups is exceeded, the oldest backup is deleted. If you set this value to zero no backup will be done.
jsp.welcome.step3.p.1: And the directory into which bibisco will save the automatic backups:
backup_directory_equal_to_projects_direc: The backup directory cannot be the same as the project directory: choose another one.
projects_directory_equal_to_backup_direc: The project directory cannot be the same as the backup directory: choose another one.
bibisco_directory_forbidden_1: bibisco does not have permission to write in the directory
bibisco_directory_forbidden_2: Unzip bibisco into another directory or run bibisco as administrator.
